revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox book |name = No Lifeguard on Duty |image = No Lifeguard on Duty by Janice Dickinson.jpg |image_size = |caption = First edition cover |alt = |author = [[Janice Dickinson]] |audio_read_by = |title_orig = No Lifeguard on Duty: The Accidental Life of the World's First Supermodel |orig_lang_code = |title_working = |translator = |illustrator = |cover_artist = |country = United States |language = English |subject = [[Supermodel]] |genre = [[Autobiography]] |published = 2002 ([[HarperCollins]]) |media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) |pages = 320 |awards = |isbn = 978-0060009465 |oclc = 50494100 |dewey = 746.9/2/092 B |congress = 2002069701 |followed_by = Everything About Me Is Fake – And I'm Perfect (2004) |wikisource = }} '''''No Lifeguard on Duty: The Accidental Life of the World's First Supermodel''''' is an [[autobiography]] by [[fashion model]], photographer, author and [[talent agent]] [[Janice Dickinson]]. It was published in hardcover format in 2002 by [[ReganBooks]], an imprint of [[HarperCollins]]. The author's friend [[make-up artist]] [[Way Bandy]] advised her to begin putting her past experiences down on paper as a form of therapy from prior trauma in her life. After gaining [[sobriety]], she started compiling her notes into book format. She contacted [[book publisher]] [[Judith Regan]] who agreed to help her publish her book after hearing her tale on the phone, without first seeing a writing sample. In November 2014, Dickinson asserted in an interview with ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' that pressure from [[Bill Cosby]] and his lawyers resulted in the removal of an account of [[sexual assault]] and [[rape]] by Cosby when she visited him at a hotel in [[Lake Tahoe]], California in 1982. After Cosby's attorney disputed this account, she reappeared on the program to proclaim she was telling the truth and explained she was speaking out publicly because of a need to be heard and to represent other women who stated they experienced a similar trauma.
The book recounts Dickinson's early life where she states she experienced [[child abuse]] from her father, and moves forward describing her experiences throughout her career as a model. Dickinson explains her struggle with [[substance dependence]] upon drugs and alcohol during her career. The author discusses her time as a representative for companies including [[Virginia Slims]], [[Max Factor]], and [[Hush Puppies]]; and her success appearing on the covers of magazines including: ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', and ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmo]]''. While performing work as a model she takes the time to gain knowledge about the craft of photography and fashion. Dickinson describes how she originated the term "[[supermodel]]". ''No Lifeguard on Duty'' cautions about the tendency towards insecurity in celebrity culture.
''No Lifeguard on Duty'' received a favorable reception from multiple publications. [[Film rights]] to the book were purchased by [[Warner Bros.]] in 2004. ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' praised the author's comedic style in the work. [[Knight Ridder|Knight Ridder Newspapers]] wrote positively of the author's courage at describing difficult experiences from her past. ''[[The New York Observer]]'' found the writing style of the book to have a good flow throughout. ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' wrote: "Dickinson comes across as a triumphant survivor."<ref name="publishersweekly" />
Dickinson's book had a positive impact on her career. Because of reading the book, [[Tyra Banks]] decided to bring Dickinson on board as a judge on her new program ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' in 2003. Dickinson served as a judge on the program for a total of four seasons before being replaced by [[Twiggy Lawson]]. [[Oxygen Network]] subsequently hired her for its new program centered on the author's efforts to start her own company; the program launched in 2006 titled: ''[[The Janice Dickinson Modeling Agency]]''.
==Writing process== Janice Dickinson's friend [[make-up artist]] [[Way Bandy]] recommended she use the writing process to help heal from her past experiences.<ref name="fitchtner" /> She began to do so as part of her addiction recovery during a [[twelve-step program]].<ref name="fitchtner" /> She put her notes down on legal pads and they became numerous over time.<ref name="fitchtner" /> By the time Dickinson began to compile her writing into book format she had become established in her career and resided in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] with her two children.<ref name="kerwin" /> She started formally putting her notes together into a book after successfully gaining [[sobriety]].<ref name="kerwin" />
She got in touch with [[book publisher]] [[Judith Regan]] who agreed to help her publish the book after a brief phone call, without first receiving a draft of the work.<ref name="fitchtner" /><ref name="wallace">Wallace 2002</ref> In an interview with ''[[Los Angeles Magazine]]'', Dickinson recalled the process of pitching her book to Regan: "I got a book deal without even turning in one shred of a writing sample. I was having an invincible moment. I told her how difficult it was for me growing up with an abusive father, how when I went to New York to become a model I was rejected for a year for being 'too ethnic.' Judith said, 'Okay, I'm in.'"<ref name="wallace" />
[[File:Janice Dickinson 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Janice Dickinson]] in 2014]] The author explained to ''Los Angeles Magazine'' her reasoning for including in the book a graphic phrase used by [[Jack Nicholson]] after his lovemaking session with her: "The reason that line made the book is because he told me not to say anything. And I will never, ever respond to anybody—man, woman, vegetable, or mineral—who tells me to keep my mouth shut. Alter what I've been through, I don't think so, pal."<ref name="wallace" />
Dickinson explained in an interview that she authored the work to communicate to others to publicly reveal their past negative experiences as a way to heal from trauma.<ref name="fitchtner" /> She stated: "I wrote this book to urge people not to keep secrets. I still suffer. The memories are still vivid. I made a lot of mistakes. I was shaped by my mistakes. But the past is done. The future's up to me."<ref name="fitchtner" />
==Contents summary== [[Janice Dickinson]] describes her early life where she suffered [[child abuse]] and [[physical abuse]] at the hands of her father.<ref name="fitchtner" /><ref name="kerwin">Kerwin 2002</ref> She writes that her three sisters and mother also experienced abuse from her father.<ref name="fitchtner" /> She recounts her ups and downs during her career while finding success in the fashion industry.<ref name="publishersweekly" /> She emphasizes how bravery is important to success, and explains how she remained firm on her request for [[United States dollar|US$]]20,000 for a modeling position when the market figure at the time was only $5,000.<ref name="publishersweekly" /> Throughout the process she experiences emotional pain from relationships that lack depth, and learns for herself about the harms of [[substance dependence]].<ref name="publishersweekly" /> Incidents related to her drug addiction problems include ingesting [[heroin]] from [[Gia Carangi]] prior to a photography session in [[Italy]], and an experience in a state of [[alcohol intoxication]] falling off a [[runway (fashion)|fashion runway]] for [[Valentino Garavani]] and landing upon [[Sophia Loren]].<ref name="fitchtner" />
The author discusses her time as a representative for companies including [[Virginia Slims]], [[Max Factor]], and [[Hush Puppies]].<ref name="publishersweekly" /> She writes of her success appearing on the covers of magazines including: ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', and ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmo]]''.<ref name="fitchtner" /> Professional photographers including [[Francesco Scavullo]], [[Norman Parkinson]], [[Irving Penn]], [[Richard Avedon]], [[Peter Beard]], and [[Michael Reinhardt]] work with her in [[photoshoot]]s.<ref name="fitchtner" /> While performing work as a model she takes the time to gain knowledge about the craft of photography and fashion.<ref name="publishersweekly" />
In the book she asserts that her experiences helped influence models who came after her including [[Cindy Crawford]] and [[Christy Turlington]].<ref name="wallace" /> She writes that she was the first to use the term "[[supermodel]]" and refers to herself as such.<ref name="wallace" /> She recounts a particular exchange with her agent Monique Pillard who asked her: "Janice, you are working night and day. Who do you think you are, superman?"<ref name="schoenberg">Schoenberg 2002</ref> Dickinson responded: "No, honey. I'm supermodel."<ref name="schoenberg" /><ref name="advocate2002">The Advocate 2002</ref>
Dickinson remembers relationships with fellow celebrities including [[Sylvester Stallone]], [[Liam Neeson]], [[Warren Beatty]], [[Mick Jagger]], and [[Jack Nicholson]].<ref name="publishersweekly" /> She enjoys her celebrity status and her time with friends [[John Belushi]], [[Truman Capote]], and [[Andy Warhol]].<ref name="wallace" /> Belushi and Dickinson enable each other's predilections for abusing drugs.<ref name="weiss" /> She regularly spends time at [[Studio 54]] during this period.<ref name="wallace" /> Dickinson recounts a darker side of celebrity, and writes that she trusted in [[Bill Cosby]] when he informed her he could help her career in [[show business]], only to experience verbal anger from him when she said she was too tired to engage in sexual activity with him.<ref name="weiss" />
She was supported during her career by her friendship with actor [[Bruce Willis]] and her positive connections with her sisters.<ref name="publishersweekly" /> She reflects on the nature of her marriages and looks back on her prior self-indulgent lifestyle.<ref name="publishersweekly" /> She explains to the reader how personal achievement may result from the allure of success, and simultaneously cautions against harmful byproducts of behavioral insecurity inherent in the mystique of celebrity.<ref name="publishersweekly" />
==Publication history== The book was published in hardcover format by [[HarperCollins]] in 2002 under its imprint [[ReganBooks]] in the United States.<ref>{{oclc|49704555}}</ref><ref>{{lccn|2002069701}}</ref> Another edition was released the same year in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{oclc|50494100}}</ref> The book was re-published in both formats in 2003, with a new cover.<ref>{{oclc|56140650}}</ref><ref>{{oclc|52695646}}</ref> ReganBooks released a subsequent edition in 2004 with a third cover re-design.<ref>{{oclc|276636119}}</ref> HarperCollins published [[eBook]] formats of the work in 2007 and 2008.<ref>{{oclc|191802672}}</ref><ref>{{oclc|229123593}}</ref> Three editions of the book were published under its third cover design in 2009.<ref>{{oclc|430496780}}</ref><ref>{{oclc|815878788}}</ref><ref>{{oclc|752954991}}</ref>
[[Warner Bros.]] purchased the [[film rights]] to the book in 2004.<ref name="mackenzie">MacKenzie 2004</ref> Dickinson subsequently turned her works into a [[trilogy]] of three books.<ref>''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' 2003</ref> She followed up on ''No Lifeguard on Duty'' with ''Everything About Me Is Fake{{spaced ndash}}And I'm Perfect'' in 2004,<ref>{{oclc|54543708}}</ref><ref>Ferrara 2004</ref> and ''Check, Please!{{spaced ndash}}Dating, Mating, and Extricating'' in 2006.<ref>{{oclc|63185772}}</ref>
==Reception== [[File:Tyra Banks 2012 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|After reading ''No Lifeguard on Duty'', [[Tyra Banks]] decided to make Janice Dickinson a judge on her television program ''[[America's Next Top Model]]''.<ref name="amatangelo" />]] ''No Lifeguard on Duty'' received a favorable review from ''[[Publishers Weekly]]''.<ref name="publishersweekly">''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' 2002</ref> The review concluded: "The book is sometimes predictable and psychologically simplistic, but Dickinson comes across as a triumphant survivor. Her willingness to recognize her own flaws makes it easy to relate to her positive message and should inspire readers searching for solutions to career and personal conflicts."<ref name="publishersweekly" /> The review praised the author's ability at being: "honest enough to acknowledge the stimulating aspects of success and glamour, explaining why they lure insecure personalities and imprison them past the point of no return."<ref name="contemporaryauthors" /> ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' reviewed the book and wrote: "What keeps the book from becoming too tawdry is Dickinson's sense of humor. She applies a healthy dose to both her conquests and disaster's alike."<ref name="kerwin" /><ref name="contemporaryauthors">''[[Contemporary Authors]]'' 2004</ref>
In a 2002 article, [[Knight Ridder|Knight Ridder Newspapers]] characterized the book as: "a brave, profane memoir of her escape from childhood abuse into the even more risky whirl of bright lights, big cities and spiraling self-destruction."<ref name="fitchtner">Fitchtner 2002</ref> A subsequent article in 2003 by Knight Ridder Newspapers wrote: "what makes Dickinson's tome stand out from all the other Hollywood memoirs is that she has a cheeky sense of humor about her self-absorption."<ref name="perry">Perry 2003</ref> [[Philip Weiss]] of ''[[The New York Observer]]'' wrote: "I read ''No Lifeguard on Duty'' at once and wasn't disappointed. Janice Dickinson is a funny and fluid narrator."<ref name="weiss">Weiss 2002</ref> Of the author's path to success recounted in the book, the ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' wrote: "Janice Dickinson had a cometlike trajectory as an early supermodel in the 1980s, which she has recounted in her raunchy life story".<ref name="fitchett">Fitchett 2002</ref>
==Impact== While reading Dickinson's book, [[English people|English]] [[novelist]] [[Jackie Collins]] ran into the author at a bookstore and asked the fellow author to lunch to discuss their mutual experiences.<ref name="kresse">Kresse 2002</ref> Janice Dickinson landed a television role as a judge on the program ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' due to ''No Lifeguard on Duty''.<ref name="amatangelo">Amatangelo 2004</ref> Show creator [[Tyra Banks]] explained to ''[[The Boston Herald]]'' her decision process: "The reason why I hired Janice Dickinson is because I read her book (''No Lifeguard on Duty: The Accidental Life of the World's First Supermodel''), and that book represented every single thing that I have never done. Every single thing that I have never experienced."<ref name="amatangelo" />
Banks elaborated that she wanted a judge on the program that had gone through issues in her modeling career that she herself had not: "I sit all the time and talk to girls and say, 'Don't drink. Don't smoke. Don't go out. Don't do this. I never did it.' But there's only so much you can preach to someone if you've never done it. I thought I could have someone like Janice because she's so outrageous."<ref name="amatangelo" /> Banks stated that she thought Dickinson provided a warning to models not to follow the path she had taken because it had proved dangerous:" When she's telling a girl, 'Don't do this,' she's saying, 'Don't do this because it didn't work for me.' I thought it was a good balance."<ref name="amatangelo" />
After serving as a judge on the program for four seasons, Dickinson's spot was filled with [[Twiggy Lawson]] in 2005 for the show's fifth season.<ref>AP Worldstream 2005</ref><ref>''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' 2005</ref> In December of the same year, [[Oxygen Network]] hired Dickinson for its new reality modeling television program which at the time was initially titled ''The Janice Dickinson Project''.<ref name="aponline2005" /> It centered on her efforts to launch her own business with a modeling agency.<ref name="aponline2005">AP Online 2005</ref> Her television show launched in 2006, titled: ''[[The Janice Dickinson Modeling Agency]]''.<ref>Hammer 2006</ref>
In a November 18, 2014 interview with Dickinson on ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'', she stated the initial version of ''No Lifeguard on Duty'' was different from what became the final published product.<ref name="davidbauder" /><ref name="billcarter" /><ref name="mattsedensky" /> Dickinson said she wrote about a traumatic experience where she said [[Bill Cosby]] [[sexual assault|sexually assaulted]] her in 1982 at a hotel in [[Lake Tahoe]], California.<ref name="davidbauder">Bauder 2014</ref><ref name="billcarter" /><ref name="emilychow">Chow 2014</ref> She stated that Cosby supplied her with [[red wine]] and then medicated her with drugs and subsequently [[rape]]d her at the hotel.<ref name="billcarter">Carter 2014</ref><ref name="mattsedensky" /><ref name="bueno2014">Bueno 2014</ref> According to Dickinson, both Cosby himself and his attorneys persuaded the author and her publisher HarperCollins to delete mention of the incident from her book prior to publication.<ref name="davidbauder" /> A few hours after the interview was publicized on ''Entertainment Tonight'', [[Netflix]] made the decision to postpone its Cosby comedy film special ''[[Bill Cosby 77]]'' from its lineup.<ref name="davidbauder" /><ref name="elber2014">Elber 2014</ref>
Martin Singer, an attorney representing Cosby, made a statement in which he asserted Dickinson was not being truthful in her account.<ref name="billcarter" /><ref name="mattsedensky">Sedensky 2014</ref> After Singer's statement, Dickinson reappeared on a subsequent broadcast of ''Entertainment Tonight'' to reassert her account from her prior interview on the program.<ref name="kevinfrazier">Frazier 2014</ref> In addition, she publicized photographs she took with a [[Polaroid camera]] of Cosby wearing a checkered bathrobe in order to support her assertions.<ref name="roig">Roig-Franzia 2014</ref> In the interview with [[Kevin Frazier]] she stated her account was the truth: "It is not a lie. It is my right as a woman. I have to speak up and you have to be able to go in and just be brave and do it for all the women that can't come forward."<ref name="kevinfrazier" /> She explained her motivation for going public and her desire for her voice to be heard: "The loss of innocence that I suffered and that these women suffered is why I'm sitting here today. And I don't care about what Cosby or networks or anybody says, you will hear me."<ref name="kevinfrazier" />
==See also== {{portal|Books|Fashion}} *[[Cover model]] *[[List of people from Florida]] *[[List of people from Brooklyn, New York]] *[[List of Vogue cover models]] *[[List of women writers]] {{clear}}

Heights)|Daily Herald]]|location=Arlington Heights, Illinois|date=November 20, 2014|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|title=Netflix Postpones Launch of Cosby Comedy Special}} *{{cite book|chapter=Dickinson, Janice|title=The Writers Directory 2005|editor1-first=Miranda Herbert |editor1-last=Ferrara|publisher=[[Gale (publisher)|St. James Press]]|isbn=978-1558625143|oclc=58973776|year=2004|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} *{{cite news|last=Fitchett|first=Joseph|date=October 3, 2002|title=The Global Class: Runway Vamp|work=[[International Herald Tribune]]|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} *{{cite news|last= Fitchtner|first= Margaria|date=August 31, 2002|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|agency=[[Knight Ridder|Knight Ridder Newspapers]]|title=Supermodel Janice Dickinson tells all about her rise to fame|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} *{{cite news|work=[[The Washington {{Infobox recurring event | name = Nušićijada | native_name = Нушићијада | logo = File:Nušićijada NEW.png | logo_caption = Official logo | image = | imagesize = | caption = | genre = [[Comedy festival]] | dates = Last week of August
24–26 August 2018 | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | location = {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Ivanjica]], Serbia | years_active = 1968–1972
2010–present | first = {{start date and age|1968}} | founder_name = | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = 55,000 (2016) | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = Ivanjica Municipality
Ivanjica Culture Centre
Ivanjica Tourism Organisation | people = | member = | website = {{URL|http://nusicijadaivanjica.rs/}} | footnotes = }} '''Nušićijada''' is an annual [[comedy festival]] held in the town of [[Ivanjica]], in the [[Moravica District|Moravica]] region of southwestern [[Serbia]]. ==History== ;1968–72 The festival began as a celebratio of film comedy from 1968 to 1972, which attracted the cultural elite of then [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]. The festival had a ''Round Scene with a Corner''. The festival bears the name of the famous Serbian comedy playwright, [[Branislav Nušić]], who used the sentence "You’re bound for Ivanjica!" as a punchline in his comedies, indicating the 19th century threat of exile to this town. Later it became the festival’s slogan and the invitation to Ivanjica. In 1972, the festival ended.{{cite web|title=ABOUT NUŠIĆIJADA|url=http://www.nusicijada.rs/en/nusicijada/|work=nusicijada.rs|accessdate=1 September 2013}} ;2010–17 [[File:Nušićijada Official Logo.png|thumb|right|2010–17 Nušićijada logo]] In 2008, a citizen petition for reviving the festival was signed by over 10% of the population. A citizen organisation named KudeS (Cultural Decentralization of Serbia) was formed and led the process of organizing the new festival. After the local Assembly adopted the proposal, the Municipality of Ivanjica, Ivanjica Culture Centre and Ivanjica Tourism Organisation joined the partnership, and these four organizations organised Nušićijada beginning in 2010.{{cite web|last=Bojović|first=Beba|title="Nušićijada" vratila sjaj staroj varoši|url=http://www.blic.rs/Vesti/Srbija/205603/Nusicijada-vratila-sjaj-staroj-varosi|work=blic.rs|accessdate=1 September 2013|language=sr}}{{cite web|last=Trtović|first=V.|title=Ivanjica opet u znaku Nušića|url=http://www.pressonline.rs/svet/balkan/131404/ivanjica-opet-u-znaku-nusica.html|work=pressonline.rs|accessdate=1 September 2013|language=sr}} According to the organizers, the 2015 Nušićijada attracted attention of more than 55,000 visitors, the most since founding.{{cite news|title=Rekordno masovno lečenje smehom zabeleženo na ivanjičkoj Nušićijadi|url=http://www.nusicijada.rs/nusicijada-zabelezila-rekordnu-posecenost/|accessdate=12 September 2015|work=nusicijada.rs|date=4 September 2015|language=Serbian}} The 2016 Nušićijada attracted 55,000 visitors again.{{cite news|title=Sedma Nušićijada oborila sve rekorde, ne odstupajući od kulturnih okvira i pravih vrednosti|url=http://www.nusicijada.rs/sedma-nusicijada-oborila-sve-rekorde-ne-odstupajuci-od-kulturnih-okvira-i-pravih-vrednosti/|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=nusicijada.rs/|date=31 August 2016|language=Serbian}} ;2018–present In March 2018, the municipality's president and local leader of ruling [[Serbian Progressive Party]], made a decision to expel KudeS (leader of the festival's revival and main organizer) from the list of event's organizers.{{cite news|last1=D.|first1=K.|title=SNS stavio Nušićijadu „pod kontrolu“|url=https://www.danas.rs/kultura/sns-stavio-nusicijadu-pod-kontrolu/|accessdate=27 March 2018|work=danas.rs|date=27 March 2018|language=Serbian}}{{cite news|title=Kao u Nušićevoj komediji: Organizatori "Nušićijade" izbačeni iz festivala koji su stvorili|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/kao-u-nusicevoj-komediji-organizatori-nusicijade-izbaceni-iz-festivala-koji-su/ev3l45s|accessdate=27 March 2018|work=blic.rs|date=27 March 2018|language=Serbian}} The move was widely seen as politically motivated, as former event's participants have satirically mocked the [[President of Serbia]] and leader of Serbian Progressive Party [[Aleksandar Vučić]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Nušićijada}} * {{Official website|http://www.nusicijada.rs}} {{small|(new website)}} * {{Official website|http://nusicijadaivanjica.rs/}} {{small|(Pre-2018 website)}} * {{facebook|nusicijada}} {{Ivanjica}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nusicijada}} [[Category:Recurring events established in 1968]] [[Category:1968 establishments in Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Cultural festivals in Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian culture]] [[Category:Tourism in Serbia]] [[Category:Summer events in Serbia]] {{Comedy-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Ancient Greek theory */ definitions are left till very late!
revision.text:
In early [[Greek music]] [[music theory|theory]], an '''octave species''' (εἶδος τοῦ διὰ πασῶν, or σχῆμα τοῦ διὰ πασῶν) is a sequence of [[incomposite interval]]s ([[ditone]]s, [[minor third]]s, [[whole tone]]s, [[semitone]]s of various sizes, or [[quarter tone]]s) making up a complete [[octave]] {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=231–32}}. The concept was also important in Medieval and Renaissance music theory. ==Ancient Greek theory== [[File:Greek Dorian enharmonic genus.png|thumb|300px|Greek Dorian octave species in the enharmonic genus, showing the two component tetrachords {{audio|Greek Dorian mode on E, enharmonic genus.mid|Play}}]] [[File:Greek Dorian chromatic genus.png|thumb|300px|Greek Dorian octave species in the chromatic genus {{audio|Greek Dorian mode on E, chromatic genus.mid|Play}}]] [[File:Dorian diatonic.png|thumb|right|300px|Greek Dorian octave species in the diatonic genus {{audio|Phrygian mode E.mid|Play}}]] Greek theorists used two terms interchangeably to describe what we call species: ''eidos'' (εἶδος) and ''skhēma'' (σχῆμα), defined as "a change in the arrangement of incomposite [intervals] making up a compound magnitude while the number and size of the intervals remains the same" ({{harvnb|Aristoxenus|1954|loc=92.7–8 & 92.9–11}} (da Rios), translated in {{harvnb|Barbera|1984|loc=230}}). Cleonides (the Aristoxenian tradition) described (in the diatonic genus) three species of [[perfect fourth|diatessaron]], four of [[perfect fifth|diapente]] and seven of [[octave|diapason]]. Ptolemy in his "Harmonics" called them all generally "species of primary consonances" (εἴδη τῶν πρώτων συμφωνιῶν). [[Boethius]], who inherited Ptolemy's generalization under the term "species primarum consonantiarum" (Inst. mus. IV,14{{Full citation needed|date=December 2014}}), expanded species theory of Greeks; along with the traditional orderings of three primary species he introduced three further their orderings {{harv|Boethius|1989|loc=149}}. For epistemology of the Antiquity music theory, the most important of all was the octave species, because "from the species of the consonance of the diapason arise what are called ''modes''" {{harv|Boethius|1989|loc=153}}. === Octave species === The basis of octave species was the smaller category of species of the [[perfect fourth]], or ''diatessaron''; when filled in with two intermediary notes, the resulting four notes and three consecutive intervals constitute a "[[tetrachord]]" {{harv|Gombosi|1951|loc=22}}. The species defined by the different positioning of the intervals within the tetrachord in turn depend upon [[Genus (music)|genus]] first being established {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=229}}. Incomposite in this context refers to intervals not composed of smaller intervals. [[File:Greek Phrygian enharmonic genus.png|thumb|300px|Greek Phrygian octave species in the enharmonic genus {{audio|Greek Phrygian mode on E, enharmonic genus.mid|Play}}]] Most Greek theorists distinguish three genera of the tetrachord: [[Enharmonic genus|enharmonic]], [[Chromatic genus|chromatic]], and [[Diatonic genus|diatonic]]. The enharmonic and chromatic genera are defined by the size of their largest incomposite interval (major third and minor third, respectively), which leaves a composite interval of two smaller parts, together referred to as a ''pyknon''; in the diatonic genus, no single interval is larger than the other two combined {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=229}}. The earliest theorists to attempt a systematic treatment of octave species, the harmonicists (or school of Eratocles) of the late fifth century BC, confined their attention to the enharmonic genus, with the intervals in the resulting seven octave species being {{harv|Barker|1984–87|loc=2:15}}: :{| class="wikitable" border="1" |- | [[Mixolydian mode|Mixolydian]] | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | 1 |- | [[Lydian mode|Lydian]] | ¼ | 2 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | 1 | ¼ |- | [[Phrygian mode|Phrygian]] | 2 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | 1 | ¼ | ¼ |- | [[Dorian mode|Dorian]] | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | 1 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 |- | [[Hypolydian mode|Hypolydian]] | ¼ | 2 | 1 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | ¼ |- | [[Hypophrygian mode|Hypophrygian]] | 2 | 1 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | ¼ | ¼ |- | [[Hypodorian mode|Hypodorian]] | 1 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 | ¼ | ¼ | 2 |} Species of the [[perfect fifth]] (''diapente'') are then created by the addition of a whole tone to the intervals of the tetrachord. The first, or original species in both cases has the ''pyknon'' or, in the diatonic genus, the semitone, at the bottom {{harv|Cleonides|1965|loc=41}} and, similarly, the lower interval of the ''pyknon'' must be smaller or equal to the higher one {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=229–30}}. The whole tone added to create the species of fifth (the "tone of disjunction") is at the top in the first species; the remaining two species of fourth and three species of fifth are regular rotations of the constituent intervals, in which the lowest interval of each species becomes the highest of the next ({{harvnb|Cleonides|1965|loc=41}}; {{harvnb|Barbera|1984|loc=233}}). Because of these constraints, tetrachords containing three different incomposite intervals (compared with those in which two of the intervals are of the same size, such as two whole tones) still have only three species, rather than the six possible permutations of the three elements {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=232}}. Similar considerations apply to the species of fifth. The species of fourth and fifth are then combined into larger constructions called "systems". The older, central "characteristic octave", is made up of two first-species tetrachords separated by a tone of disjunction, and is called the Lesser Perfect System {{harv|Gombosi|1951|loc=23–24}}. It therefore includes a lower, first-species fifth and an upper, fourth-species fifth. To this central octave are added two flanking conjuct tetrachords (that is, they share the lower and upper tones of the central octave). This constitutes the Greater Perfect System, with six fixed bounding tones of the four tetrachords, within each of which are two movable pitches. {{harvnb|Ptolemy|1930|loc=D. 49–53}} {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=235}} labels the resulting fourteen pitches with the (Greek) letters from Α ([[Alpha (letter)|Alpha α]]) to Ο ([[Omega (letter)|Omega Ω]]). (A diagram is available at [[Musical system of ancient greece#Systêma ametabolon, an overview of the Tone System|systema ametabolon]]) The Lesser and Greater Perfect Systems exercise constraints on the possible octave species. Some early theorists, such as Gaudentius in his ''Harmonic Introduction'', recognized that, if the various available intervals could be combined in any order, even restricting species to just the diatonic genus would result in twelve ways of dividing the octave (and his 17th-century editor, [[Marcus Meibom]], pointed out that the actual number is 21), but "only seven species or forms are melodic and symphonic" {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=237–39}}. Those octave species that cannot be mapped onto the system are therefore rejected {{harv|Barbera|1984|loc=240}}. ==Medieval theory== In chant theory beginning in the 9th century, the ''New Exposition'' of the composite treatise called ''Alia musica'' developed an eightfold [[Musical mode|modal system]] from the seven diatonic octave species of ancient Greek theory, transmitted to the West through the Latin writings of [[Martianus Capella]], [[Cassiodorus]], [[Isidore of Seville]], and, most importantly, Boethius. Together with the species of fourth and fifth, the octave species remained in use as a basis of the theory of modes, in combination with other elements, particularly the system of [[Hagiopolitan Octoechos|octoechos]] borrowed from the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] {{harv|Powers|2001}}. Species theory in general (not just the ''octave'' species) remained an important theoretical concept throughout Middle Ages. The following appreciation of species as a structural basis of a mode, found in the ''Lucidarium'' (XI, 3) of [[Marchetto of Padua|Marchetto]] (ca. 1317), can be seen as typical:
We declare that those who judge the mode of a melody exclusively with regard to ascent and descent cannot be called musicians, but rather blind men, singers of mistake... for, as [[Berno of Reichenau|Bernard]] said, "species are dishes at a musical banquet; they create modes" {{harv|Herlinger|1985|loc=393-395}}.
==Sources== * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Aristoxenus|1954}}|reference=[[Aristoxenus]]. 1954. ''Aristoxeni elementa harmonica'', edited by Rosetta da Rios. Rome: Typis Publicae Officinae Polygraphicae.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Barker|1984–89}}|reference=Barker, Andrew (ed.) (1984–89). ''Greek Musical Writings''. 2 vols. Cambridge & New York: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-23593-6}} (v. 1) {{ISBN|0-521-30220-X}} (v. 2).}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Barbera|1984}}|reference=Barbera, André. 1984. "Octave Species". ''The Journal of Musicology'' 3, no. 3 (Summer): 229–41.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Boethius|1989}}|reference=[[Boethius]]. 1989. ''Fundamentals of Music'', translated, with introduction and notes by Calvin M. Bower; edited by Claude V. Palisca. Music Theory Translation Series. New Haven and London: Yale University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-300-03943-6}}.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Cleonides|1965}}|reference=[[Cleonides]]. 1965. "Harmonic Introduction," translated by Oliver Strunk. In ''Source Readings in Music History'', vol. 1 (Antiquity and the Middle Ages), edited by Oliver Strunk, 34–46. New York: W. W. Norton.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Gombosi|1951}}|reference=Gombosi, Otto. 1951. "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/830117, Mode, Species]". ''Journal of the American Musicological Society'' 4, no. 1 (Spring): 20–26.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Herlinger|1985}}|reference=Herlinger, Jan (ed.) (1985). ''The Lucidarium of Marchetto of Padua''. Chicago & London: The University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0-226-32762-0}}.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Powers|2001}}|reference=[[Harold Powers|Powers, Harold S]]. 2001. "Mode §II: Medieval Modal Theory". ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', second edition, edited by [[Stanley Sadie]] and [[John Tyrrell (professor of music)|John Tyrrell]]. London: Macmillan Publishers.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Prolemy|1930}}|reference=[[Ptolemy]]. 1930. ''Die Harmonielehre des Klaudios Ptolemaios'', edited by Ingemar Düring. Göteborgs högskolas årsskrift 36, 1930:1. Göteborg: Elanders boktr. aktiebolag. Reprint, New York: Garland Publishing, 1980.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Ptolemy|2000}}|reference=Ptolemy. 2000. ''Harmonics'', translated and commentary by Jon Solomon. [[Mnemosyne (journal)|Mnemosyne]], Bibliotheca Classica Batava, Supplementum, 0169-8958, 203. Leiden and Boston: Brill. {{ISBN|90-04-11591-9}}.}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Solomon|1984}}|reference=Solomon, Jon. 1984. "Towards a History of Tonoi". ''The Journal of Musicology'' 3, no. 3 (Summer): 242–51.}} ==Further reading== * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Anon.|n.d.}}|reference=Anon. n.d. "[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9056731/octave-species Octave Species]". Encyclopedia Britannica (online edition, accessed 5 September 2014)}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Chalmers|1993}}|reference=Chalmers, John H. Jr. 1993. ''Divisions of the Tetrachord''. Hanover, NH: Frog Peak Music. {{ISBN|0-945996-04-7}} available on-line http://eamusic.dartmouth.edu/~larry/published_articles/divisions_of_the_tetrachord/index.html}} * {{wikicite|ref={{harvid|Warburton|2000}}|reference=Warburton, Jane. 2000. "Questions of Attribution and Chronology in Three Medieval Texts on Species Theory". ''Music Theory Spectrum'' 22, no. 2:225–35.}} [[Category:Greek music]] [[Category:Musical scales]] [[Category:Music theory]]

revision.comment: /* In popular culture */ Not related to actual plate spinning
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2015}} [[Image:Opening Ceremony Plate Spinning.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Plate Spinners]]'''Plate spinning''' is a circus manipulation art where a person spins [[Plate (dishware)|plates]], [[Bowl (vessel)|bowls]] and other flat objects on poles, without them falling off. Plate spinning relies on the [[gyroscope|gyroscopic]] effect, in the same way a [[top]] stays upright while spinning. Spinning plates are sometimes gimmicked, to help keep the plates on the poles.
Many [[Chinese acrobatics]] troupes feature plate spinning, usually in combination with [[contortion]] or [[acrobatic]] skills. These usually feature performers holding several plates in each hand spinning on sticks.
Western plate spinning performers usually present comedy acts and typically feature one performer with an assistant, spinning multiple plates on sticks held vertically in stands.
Other forms of plate manipulation include plate waltzing, where plates are spun on their edges on a table top, and plate juggling, where plates are manipulated and thrown by the performers. Some performers have combined several of these elements into restaurant or kitchen-themed acts.
The [[Guinness World Record]] for spinning multiple plates is held by David Spathaky, assisted by Debbie Woolley, who spun 108 plates simultaneously in Bangkok, Thailand, on television in 1996. He had previously held and broken his own record four times since 1986.
==In popular culture== [[Image:Efteling Carnaval Festival Loeki China.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Chinese Plate Spinners at [[Carnival Festival|Carnaval Festival]], [[Efteling]]]] The tune "[[Sabre Dance]]" is often played in the background. This was a popular act on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' (by Erich Brenn[http://www.edsullivan.com/artists/erich-brenn-plate-spinner]) and other American [[variety show|variety]] and [[talent show]]s during the early years of American television. [[Tom Griswold]], co-host of ''[[The Bob & Tom Show]]'', a syndicated American comedy radio program, occasionally says he wishes he could see a plate spinner on TV again and wants to book one for his staff's annual Christmas party, which [[Chick McGee]] cites as further evidence that Griswold is out of touch with contemporary entertainment. In an episode of the ''[[The Simpsons|Simpsons]]'', at the [[Springfield Retirement Castle]] talent show, one participant does a similar act, but uses the [[dentures]] of several of the residents. Plate spinning was often seen in [[HBO]]'s prison drama ''[[Oz (TV series)|Oz]]'', where an unnamed prisoner would often be seen spinning a book on the tip of a pen.
On British television, the popular game show ''[[The Generation Game]]'' would regularly feature a plate spinner demonstrating his skills, then inviting the contestants to have a go - with smashing results. During the 1960s & 1970s Wolfgang Bartchelli popularised plate spinning in Europe and regularly appeared on television. From the 1980s onward, plate spinner [[Andrew Van Buren]] regularly appeared and still can be seen presenting this format on game shows, on television and performing around the world.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Plate spinning}} * [http://www.platespinning.com/learn/ Learn to spin and juggle plates]
{{Object manipulation}}
[[Category:Circus skills]]

[[Film Agency of Republic of Macedonia]] | distributor = | budget = | network = [[RTS1|RTS 1]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[HDTV]]) | audio_format = | first_run = | released = | first_aired = {{Start date|df=yes|2017|10|22}} | last_aired = ''Ongoing'' | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''''Shadows over Balkan''''' ({{lang-sr|Сенке над Балканом}} / Senke nad Balkanom), also known as '''''Black Sun''''' is a [[Cinema of Serbia|Serbian]] [[Crime film|crime]] [[Television show|television series]] created by [[Dragan Bjelogrlić]]. Besides Bjelogrlić, [[screenplay]] was also done by [[Danica Pajović]], [[Dejan Stojiljković]] and [[Vladimir Kecmanović]], based on a story written by Stevan Koprivica. The series was done in co-production with [[Cobra Film]], [[Radio Television of Serbia]], [[Skopje Film Studio]], [[Iskra (film production)|Iskra]], [[Radio Televizija Republike Srpske|RTRS]], [[Macedonian Radio Television]] and [[The Film Agency of the Republic of Macedonia]]. The series is set in the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]] during the [[Interwar period]] and follows the story of two [[Belgrade]] police department [[Police Inspector|inspectors]]. The first season is set during the period just before the [[6 January Dictatorship]] and follows the attempts of the two inspectors to solve the cases of [[Human sacrifice|sacrificial murders]] which were shaking the Belgrade public. Dragan Bjelogrlić, [[Andrija Kuzmanović]], [[Marija Bergam]], [[Aleksandr Galibin]], [[Nenad Jezdić]], [[Gordan Kičić]], [[Nebojša Dugalić]], [[Sebastian Cavazza]] and [[Toni Mihajlovski]] are in the lead roles. The first season ran from 22. October 2017 to 24. December 2017 on the [[RTS1]] channel, as well as on many other television channels from former Yugoslavia. The filming of the first season took place between October 2016 and June 2017, while the second season will be filmed during 2018 and will be airing in 2019. The first season was received very well by both the audience and critics, although it caused some controversy. Production, acting, editing and costume design have all been praised, as well as the themes the series deals with. == Premise == The series is divided in three seasons and encompasses the period between 1928 and 1940.{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/magazine/sr/story/411/film-i-tv/2577156/zavrseno-snimanje-prvog-dela-serije-senke-nad-balkanom.html|title=Završeno snimanje prvog dela serije „Senke nad Balkanom“|publisher=[[Radio Television of Serbia]] |date = |accessdate = 28 December 2016}} The first season covers the period just before the assassination of the Croatian Member of National Assembly [[Stjepan Radić]] at the [[Parliament of Yugoslavia|National Assembly of the Serbs, Croatians and Slovenians]] and the subsequent establishment of [[6 January Dictatorship|the dictatorship]]. [[Belgrade]] in between two World Wars was chosen as the main setting for the series. At the center of events we find the main characters – fifty year old criminal police inspector Andra Tanasijević Tane and his new associate, a young [[Forensic pathology|forensic]] by the name of Stanko Pletikosić. Belgrade is portrayed as a place where crime consists of classic [[Robbery|robberies]] and [[Murder|murders]], but whose biggest problems are wars between [[opium]] [[cartel]]s, which use the city as just another route for [[smuggling]] the expensive and precious drug further into [[Europe]] and [[United States]]. The plot of the first season starts with a very peculiar and brutal murder which occurs at a [[Costume party|costume ball]] where most of the Belgrade's [[social elite]] is gathered.{{cite web|url=http://mondo.rs/a1052492/Zabava/TV/Senke-nad-Balkanom-druga-epizoda.html|title=SENKE NAD BALKANOM: Još jedno jezivo ubistvo!|publisher=mondo.rs |date = |accessdate = 29 October 2017}} Inspector Tanasijević soon realizes that the cause of the frequent eerie events, which are beginning to grow in number by the day, is an [[Relic|ancient relic]] – [[Holy Lance]] (with which [[Jesus]] was pierced through on the [[Crucifixion|cross]]) – to which mystical powers are ascribed.{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/magazine/ci/story/401/film-i-tv/2912664/senke-nad-balkanom-veceras-stizu-na-male-ekrane.html|title=„Сенке над Балканом“ вечерас стижу на мале екране!|date=|publisher=[[Radio Television of Serbia]]|accessdate=22 October 2017}} He realizes that there are people who are ready to do anything to have it in their possession and is sucked into the entangled web of crime of which all the obscure interest groups from the Balkans from that time are part of the Russian [[White army]] of general [[Pyotr Wrangel|Vrangel]], the secret police of the [[Soviet Union]] ([[OGPU]] and [[NKVD]]), [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]], [[IMRO]], [[Yugoslav Communists|Yugoslav communists]], the underbelly of Belgrade and [[secret society]] called [[Thule Society|Thule]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kurir.rs/zabava/pop-kultura/2948551/senke-nad-balkanom-razotkrivaju-tajne-slobodnih-zidara-masoni-nisu-sekli-glave-ali-su-krojili-istoriju-srbije|title=SENKE NAD BALKANOM RAZOTKRIVAJU TAJNE SLOBODNIH ZIDARA: Masoni nisu sekli glave ali su krojili istoriju Srbije|publisher=[[Kurir (Newspapers)|Kurir]] |date = |accessdate = 28 November 2017}} Following the traces of the committed crimes, the inspector starts looking for relic with one goal in mind – to remove it from Belgrade and prevent more innocent deaths. == Roles == [[Dragan Bjelogrlić]] played the main role of inspector Tane, and he was also the [[Film producer|producer]] and [[Film director|director]]. [[Gordan Kičić]] played the role of Alimpije Mirić, one of the main antagonists. He said that he saw the [[Screenplay (TV series)|screenplay]] as far back as 2014. He filmed his scenes in the first season from October 2016 to May 2017. He didn’t film his scenes in continuity but in parts which lasted a couple of days.{{cite web|last1=Pandurević|first1=Dragana|last2=Milenković|first2=Stefan|title=Gordan Kičić za NOIZZ: Tajna Alimpija Mirića iz "Senki nad Balkanom"|url=https://noizz.rs/intervju/gordan-kicic-za-noizz-tajna-alimpija-mirica-iz-senki-nad-balkanom/rh24ksj|website=Noizz.rs|accessdate=30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date=18 December 2017}} [[Nenad Jezdić]], who plays the antagonist by the name of Krojač (Tailor), at first wished to play the role of inspector Tane. The role of Krojač was his last available choice. Slovenian actor [[Sebastian Cavazza]] got the role of Gabriel Maht.{{cite web|title=Osvojio žensku publiku: Ko je markantni Sebastijan Kavaca iz serije “Senke nad Balkanom”?|url=http://www.gloria.rs/price/osvojio-zensku-publiku-ko-je-markantni-sebastijan-kavaca-iz-serije-senke-nad-balkanom/|website=Gloria|accessdate=30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date=31 December 2017}} The role of general [[Pyotr Wrangel|Vrangel]] went to the Russian actor [[Aleksandr Galibin]], who remarked that he was delighted to play such an important historical figure: "It is such a precious thing to me to be playing such an important historical figure as general Vrangel was. I am particularly glad that we are filming in this church, where his body rests. That is especially touching."{{cite web|last1=Serbia|first1=RTS, Radio televizija Srbije, Radio Television of|title=Александар Галибин у серији "Сенке над Балканом"|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/rts/ci/rtspredstavlja/story/210/snima-se/2553156/aleksandar-galibin-u-seriji-senke-nad-balkanom.html|website=RTS.rs|accessdate=30 December 2017|language=sr-RS}} In the second season, the Slovenian actor [[Jernej Šugman]], who passed away in December 2017, was supposed to play the role of [[Anton Korošec]] minister of internal affairs of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia.{{cite web|last1=Teran Košir|first1=Alenka|last2=Mrevlje|first2=Než|title=Bjelogrlić: Magnifico je v Srbiji precej večja zvezda, kot si misli #intervju|url=https://siol.net/trendi/film/dragan-bjelogrlic-magnifico-je-v-srbiji-vecja-zvezda-kot-si-misli-intervju-456215|website=Sio1NET.|accessdate=31 January 2018|language=sl}} The role of Stanko Pletikosić was supposed to be played by [[Miloš Biković]], with whom Bjelogrlić already collaborated on "[[Montevideo, God Bless You!]]", but Biković gave up because of the obligations he had in Russia. [[Andrija Kuzmanović]] got the role in the end who also acted in "Montevideo".{{cite web|last1=Radanov|first1=Ljubomir|title=BJELOGRLIĆ POSLE SMRTI KUMA PROMENIO SCENARIO: Mandinu ulogu izbrisao iz serije Senke nad Balkanom|url=http://www.kurir.rs/zabava/pop-kultura/2944521/bjelogrlic-posle-smrti-kuma-promenio-scenario-mandinu-ulogu-izbrisao-iz-serije-senke-nad-balkanom|website=kurir.rs|accessdate=30 December 2017|language=sr-RS}} [[Brankica Sebastijanović]] and [[Marija Bergam]] were two main contenders for the role of Maja Davidović, with Bergam getting the role. Macedonian actor [[Toni Mihajlovski]] plays the role of Damjan Hadži Arsov, a fictitious member of [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization]]. Dejan Stojiljković, who is one of the screenwriters, said that his character is not based on [[Ivan Mihailov|Vanča Mihailov]], but "has more similarities with Bulgarian revolutionary [[Dame Gruev]]".{{cite web|last1=Stojiljković|first1=dejan|title=BARUT, HEROIN I REVOLUCIJA Kako je delovala ZLOGLASNA TERORISTIČKA ORGANIZACIJA VMRO i njihovo carstvo droge i smrti|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/barut-heroin-i-revolucija-kako-je-delovala-zloglasna-teroristicka-organizacija-vmro-i/kjyywh3|website=Blic.rs|accessdate=8 February 2018|language=sr-RS|date=17 December 2017}} Macedonian actress [[Jana Stojanovska]] plays the role of Macedonian revolutionary Jovana, who is the sister of Damjan Hadži Arsov. Her character was based on [[Mara Buneva]], also the member of Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization. The role of the owner of the tavern "Savsko bure", who deserted the [[Austro-Hungarian Army|Austro-Hungarian army]] by managing to get across [[Sava|Sava river]] in a barrel is played by [[Aleksandar Stojković (actor)|Aleksandar Stojković Piksi]]. [[Vladimir Vuletić]], the vice president of [[FK Partizan]], had a [[Cameo appearance|cameo role]] as one of the Thule henchman.{{cite web|last1=Mitrović|first1=Darko|title=''Grobari'' u neverici! Član uprave Partizana u ''Senkama nad Balkanom''!|url=https://www.sportske.net/vest/domaci-fudbal/grobari-u-neverici-clan-uprave-partizana-u-senkama-nad-balkanom-321760.html|website=Sportske.net|accessdate=26 January 2018}} == Episodes == {{Series overview | color1 = #C14F36 | link1 = List of episodes of Shadows over Balkan#Season 1 (2017) | episodes1 = 10 | start1 = {{Start date|df=yes|2017|10|22}} | end1 = {{End date|df=yes|2017|12|24}} | color2 = # | link2 = List of episodes of Shadows over Balkan#Season 2 (TBA) | episodes2 = TBA | start2 = {{Start date|df=yes|2019||}} | end2 = {{Start date|df=yes|2019||}} | color3 = # | link3 = List of episodes of Shadows over Balkan#Season 3 (TBA) | episodes3 = TBA | start3 = TBA | end3 = TBA }} Series is planned to have three seasons.{{fact|date=November 2018}} First season had ten episodes and dealt with the time period just before the [[6 January Dictatorship|6. January dictatorship]]. Second season is planned to deal with the time period before the Marseilles assassination of [[Alexander I of Yugoslavia|King Alexander I of Yugoslavia,]] while the third season will be set just before start of World War Two in Kingdom of Yugoslavia. == Screenings == [[File:Senke nad Balkanom Pijaca.jpg|thumb|left|Set that served as a [[marketplace]] in [[Baranda]].]] Pre-premiere in [[Serbia]] was on 17 October 2017 at [[Yugoslav Film Archive]].{{cite web|last1=Milanović|first1=Milorad|title=Na premijeri serije "Senke nad Balkanom" Beograd je izgledao kao Holivud|url=https://noizz.rs/kultura/na-premijeri-serije-senke-nad-balkanom-beograd-je-izgledao-kao-holivud/3vst4yv?placement=LinkRelated|website=Noizz.rs|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date = 18 October 2017}} The series had a premiere in Serbia on [[Radio Television of Serbia|RTS]] on 12 October 2017 and had a time slot at 8 pm, which has long been the default time slot for all Serbian and Yugoslav TV series.{{cite web|last1=Radosavljević|first1=Radmila|title=Dragan Bjelogrlić: Ovde ljubav i mržnja idu ruku pod ruku|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/kultura.71.html:699077-Dragan-Bjelogrlic-Ovde-ljubav-i-mrznja-idu-ruku-pod-ruku|website=www.novosti.rs|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-Latn}}{{cite web|last1=Božović|first1=Milojko|title=BURA ZBOG BJELOGRLIĆEVE SERIJE Zašto se "Senke nad Balkanom" ne emituju u Hrvatskoj|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/bura-zbog-bjelogrliceve-serije-zasto-se-senke-nad-balkanom-ne-emituju-u-hrvatskoj/xj1s5fg|website=Blic.rs|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date = 10 November 2017}} The first episode in Serbia was watched by more than 2.123.000 viewers and was the most watched media on that channel.{{cite web|title=RTS obara sopstvene rekorde!|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/magazine/sr/story/411/film-i-tv/2913615/vise-od-21-milion-gledalaca-uz-premijeru-serije-senke-nad-balkanom.html|website=RTS.rs|accessdate = 19 January 2018|language=sr-RS}} The premiere in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] was at the 23th [[Sarajevo Film Festival]], where two episodes which received ovations were shown.{{cite web|last1=Bakić|first1=Edina|title=Dragan Bjelogrlić za “Dnevni avaz”: Čovjek se teško miri s tim da primitivci odlučuju o našim sudbinama|url=http://avaz.ba/vijesti/intervju/293173/dragan-bjelogrlic-za-%E2%80%9Cdnevni-avaz%E2%80%9D-covjek-se-tesko-miri-s-tim-da-primitivci-odlucuju-o-nasim-sudbinama|website=Avaz.ba|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=bs-BA}} The first season was airing on [[Radio Televizija Republike Srpske|RTRS]]. In [[Montenegro]] the series is aired on [[RTCG|RTCG 1]], and in [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] on [[MRT 1]]. The series debuted in Macedonia at the 38. [[Manaki Brothers Film Festival]] in [[Bitola]] on 25 September 2017, and Dragan Bjelogrlić, [[Tomi Salkovski]] (co-producer), [[Igor Ivanov Izi]] (director on one of the episodes) as well as the actors Marija Bergam, Jana Stojanovska, [[Pero Arsovski]] and [[Petar Atanovski]] addressed the audience.{{cite web|last1=Janković|first1=Zoran|title=„Senke nad Balkanom“ predstavljene i na festivalu u Bitolju « FCS|url=http://www.fcs.rs/16118/|website=Filmski centar Srbije|accessdate = 22 January 2018}} There was a great controversy in [[Croatia|Croatian]] media for not airing the first season, and the reasons cited were that it was due to the character of [[Ante Pavelić]] and also that Dragan Bjelogrlić himself forbade it. Bjelogrlić dismissed these claims and said that the main reason for the series not airing in Croatia was because no channel acquired the rights to air. The series was to start airing in [[Russia]] in December 2017. In [[Slovenia]] it’s been airing since 7 January 2018. on [[Planet TV]].{{cite web|url=https://siol.net/planet-tv/filmi-serije/na-planet-prihaja-najbolj-provokativna-serija-balkana-454552|title=Na Planet TV prihaja najbolj provokativna serija Balkana|publisher=siol.net |date = 27 December 2017 |accessdate = 27 December 2017}} The managing director of RTS [[Dragan Bujošević]] confirmed in an interview for [[Večernje novosti|Večernje Novosti]] on 14 January 2018 that RTS won’t be airing the second season because of the high price Cobra Film asked for.{{cite web|last1=Matović|first1=D.|last2=Adžić|first2=M.|title=Dragan Bujošević za “Novosti”: Hajku na "Nemanjiće" podmetnuli na "tviteru"|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/scena.147.html:706101-Dragan-Bujosevic-za-Novosti-Hajku-na-Nemanjice-podmetnuli-na-tviteru|website=www.novosti.rs|accessdate = 15 January 2018|language=sr-Latn}} In an interview for [[N1 (television)|N1]] TV on 3 January 2018. Dragan Bjelogrlić named [[HBO]] and [[Top TV (Serbian TV channel)|Top TV]] which is owned by [[Serbia Broadband|SBB]] as the highest bidders for the new season, while RTS gave the lowest bid. Bjelogrlić gave 2019 as the year in which the second season will be airing.{{fact|date=November 2018}} The name of the series was translated into English as "[[Black Sun (occult symbol)|Black Sun]]" which refers to the symbol that can be frequently in the series and also "Shadows over Balkan".{{cite web|title=Black Sun / Senke nad Balkanom|url=https://films.sff.ba/en/detail/?film=Black-Sun|website=Sarajevo Film Festival|accessdate = 26 January 2018}} == Production and inspiration == {{multiple image | width = 215 | direction = vertical | footer = Some of the location where the series was shot is village [[Bukovo]] (up) and [[Slivnica Monastery]] near village [[Slivnica (Resen Municipality)|Slivnica]] (bottom). | image1 = Bukovo-glavna-ulica.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Slivnicki-Manastir-MKD.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = }} Dragan Bjelogrlić first got interested in the time period in which the series is set while filming the TV series as well as the movie version of [[Montevideo, God Bless You!]] He got interested in [[Interwar period|this period]] because he knew very little of it and he also thought that the Serbian public in general isn’t well informed about it: "Our destiny was such that we never learned much about that time period, it was almost never talked about. And those were important and in a way intense times, especially in Yugoslavia." {{cite news|last1=Pivljanin|first1=Ranko|title=GOST "BLICA" Dragan Bjelogrlić: Srbi ne menjaju nameštaj, a ne politički sistem za koji se slažemo da ne valja|url=https://www.blic.rs/vesti/drustvo/gost-blica-dragan-bjelogrlic-srbi-ne-menjaju-namestaj-a-ne-politicki-sistem-za-koji/4ledhm1|accessdate = 30 December 2017|work=Blic.rs|date = 14 August 2017|language=sr-RS}}{{cite web|last1=Katavić|first1=Ivan|title=Bjelogrlić: Nije sjajno kada imate bolju prošlost nego sadašnjost|url=https://www.slobodnaevropa.org/a/intervju-dragan-bjelogrlic/28686990.html|website=Radio Slobodna Evropa|accessdate = 30 December 2017}} The fact that Yugoslavia was called "[[Illegal drug trade in Colombia|Colombia of Europe]]" between the two Wars also served as an inspiration to him. [[File:Dejan Stojiljković i Aleksandar Galibin - Senke nad Balkanom.jpg|thumb|One of the series screenwriter [[Dejan Stojiljković]] and Russian actor [[Aleksandr Galibin]] who plays [[Pyotr Wrangel|General Vrangel]] on the set out side [[Hotel Moskva, Belgrade|hotel Moskva]] in Belgrade.]] In his article for [[Blic]] he wrote that he didn’t want to compromise on any part of the show’s creation: "Shadows over Balkan is a piece for which I tried to make no compromises. There were no compromises on any level and in any phase of the show’s production. From the [[Screenplay (TV series)|screenplay]], [[Storytelling|story]], [[theme (narrative)|theme]]s, national divisions, [[aesthetics]], direction to the [[Film budgeting|budget]] and cost. I didn’t want to concern myself with the acquired taste of the RTS audience, [[Television content rating system|ratings]], [[political correctness]], [[Puritans|puritan]] [[Morality|moral principles]], conservative historians, [[Second Serbia|first and second Serbia]], and the like…" He seriously doubted in the success of the show, because "in aesthetic, dramaturgic and narrative aspects it was different than everything else he worked on in the past."{{cite web|last1=Bjelogrli'|first1=Dragan|title=Autorski tekst Dragana Bjelogrlića: Zašto su mi "Senke" važne|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/autorski-tekst-dragana-bjelogrlica-zasto-su-mi-senke-vazne/7bce9mq|website=Blic.rs|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date = 22 October 2017}} He was inspired by a number of [[Television in the United States|American]], [[Television in Germany|German]], [[Television in Italy|Italian]], [[Scandinavia|Scandinavian]] and [[Eastern Europe|Eastern European]] TV series, and as the main source of inspiration he cited [[Boardwalk Empire]]. He was also inspired by the connection between [[crime]] and [[corruption]] saying how "when he put some things in order, he came to the conclusion that there exists a historic constant which affects [[Balkans|this region]], because it is of utmost importance that when you are working on a piece of art which deals with the past, it is important to focus on the moment from which you are doing it."{{cite web|title=SENKE NAD BALKANOM: Istina ili fikcija? (FOTO)|url=http://mondo.rs/a1066339/Zabava/TV/Senke-nad-Balkanom-istorija-i-fikcija.html|website=Mondo Portal|accessdate = 22 January 2018|language=sr-Latn}} The filming of the first season took place between 1 October 2016 and end of July 2017.{{cite web|title=Dragan Bjelogrlić završio snimanje serije “Senke nad Balkanom”, premijera na jesen na RTS-u|url=http://www.hellomagazin.rs/zivot/dragan-bjelogrlic-zavrsio-snimanje-serije-senke-nad-balkanom-premijera-na-jesen-na-rts-u/|website=Hello! magazin|accessdate = 30 December 2017}}{{cite web|title='Senke nad Balkanom'- završeno snimanje prve sezone serije - Ženska TV|url=http://www.zenska.tv/senke-nad-balkanom-zavrseno-snimanje-prve-sezone-serije/|website=Ženska TV|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date = 14 July 2017}} The series was shot on many different locations in [[Belgrade]], Macedonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and a new [[film studio]] was also built in [[Baranda]].{{cite web|title=Sa ’Senkama nad Balkanom’, Bjela pomera granice - Ženska TV|url=http://www.zenska.tv/sa-senkama-nad-balkanom-bjela-pomera-granice/|website=Ženska TV|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS|date = 5 March 2017}} Poor part of Belgrade from that period was constructed here -[[Jatagan Mala]] with fictive [[Kafana|kafanas]] named "Kod Nišliju" (''At Niški's'') and "Savsko bure" (''[[Sava]] barrel''), [[Pištoljmala]] and [[Savamala]]), as well as the richer part with a [[marketplace]], a [[Candy Shop|candy shop]] and a [[quilt shop]], as well as a [[Barber|barber shop]]. According to Bjelogrlić, 30% of the filming took place in Baranda. {{cite web|last1=Džodan|first1=Neven|title=Bjelogrlić pokazao svoj HOLIVUD U BARANDI! Pogledajte gde se snima serija "Senke nad Balkanom"|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/bjelogrlic-pokazao-svoj-holivud-u-barandi-pogledajte-gde-se-snima-serija-senke-nad/pqk58n4|website=Blic.rs|accessdate = 24 January 2018|language=sr-RS|date = 28 September 2016}} Some particular scenes were shot on [[Zrenjanin]] streets as well as in its [[Zrenjanin City Hall|City Hall]].{{cite web|title=Deo serije "Senke nad Balkanom" upravo se snima u Zrenjaninu|url=https://ilovezrenjanin.com/aktuelno/deo-serije-senke-nad-balkanom-upravo-se-snima-u-zrenjaninu/|website=ilovezrenjanin.com|accessdate = 5 February 2018|language=sr-RS}}{{cite web|title=Nastavak snimanja serije "Senke nad Balkanom" u Zrenjaninu (8 SLIKA)|url=https://ilovezrenjanin.com/aktuelno/nastavak-snimanja-serije-senke-nad-balkanom-u-zrenjaninu-8-slika/|website=ilovezrenjanin.com|accessdate = 5 February 2018|language=sr-RS}} Some scenes were supposed to be filmed in Slovenia as well, RTV Slovenija was in support of this, but it was later abandoned due to financial reasons. [[File:Miloš Samolov i Dragan Bjelogrlić.jpg|thumb|[[Miloš Samolov]] (left) and [[Dragan Bjelogrlić]] (right) on set of TV Series in kafana "Kod Nišliju".]] Together with Bjelogrlić, the screenplay was worked on by screenwriters [[Danica Pajović]], [[Dejan Stojiljković]] and [[Vladimir Kecmanović]] adapted to a film story by [[Stevan Koprivica]].{{cite web|title=Senke nad Balkanom|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/tv/sr/story/20/rts-1/2906043/senke-nad-balkanom.html|website=Radio televizija Srbije|accessdate = 30 December 2017|language=sr-RS}} Koprivica worked on some of the early episodes, and according to Danica Pajović, "the story was a [[Arthur Conan Doyle|Conan-Doyle type]] [[Mysticism|mystic]] [[drama]] about two inspectors who are working on resolving a series of sacrificial murders in Belgrade set between the two Wars. Bjelogrlić then expanded the theme to the Belgrade underbelly and [[Opium|opium trade]] in Yugoslavia and convoluted the story to such an extent that Dejan Stojiljković and I had to join the screenwriters team, with Vladimir Kecmanović also joining us later."{{cite web|last1=Pajović|first1=Danica|title=Danica Pajović: Kako smo "preživeli" Bjelogrlića|url=https://www.blic.rs/kultura/vesti/danica-pajovic-kako-smo-preziveli-bjelogrlica/4vyw9mz|website=Blic|accessdate = 21 January 2018|language=sr-RS|date = 22 July 2017}} According to his own words, this was the first time Dejan Stojiljković wrote a screenplay for a movie or a TV series. [[Magnifico (musician)|Robert Pešut Magnifico]], with whom Bjelogrlić already collaborated on ''Montevideo '', worked on the [[soundtrack]] for the series. [[Ognjen Radivojević]] sang the song in the title sequence, and he was chosen by Magnifico and Bjelogrlić "because of his specific tone of voice and emotions which emerge from his vocal range."{{cite web|last1=Badjuk|first1=Mario|title=BJELA JE TEŽAK ČOVEK! Manjifiko otkrio kako je sarađivati sa srpskim glumcem i rediteljem! - Informer|url=http://informer.rs/zabava/televizija/359578/bjela-je-tezak-covek-manjifiko-otkrio-kako-je-saradivati-sa-srpskim-glumcem-i-rediteljem|website=Informer|accessdate = 21 January 2018|language=sr-Latn-RS}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat|Shadow over Balkans}} * {{IMDb title|id=6108262|title=Senke nad Balkanom}} * [https://www.facebook.com/SenkeNadBalkanom/ Official Facebook page] * [https://twitter.com/senkenadblknm Official Twitter page] * [http://www.cobrafilm.com/site1/srpski.html Official page of Cobra film] [[category:Cinema of Serbia]] [[Category: Crime television series]] [[category:Serbian crime television series]] [[category:2017 Serbian television series debuts]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Spuds mackenzie.jpg|thumb|Spuds MacKenzie in an ad]]
'''Spuds MacKenzie''' is a fictional dog character created for use in an extensive advertising campaign marketing [[Anheuser-Busch brands#Bud Light|Bud Light]] beer in the late 1980s. The Spuds MacKenzie [[mascot]] and campaign were created by a 23-year-old art director, Jon Moore. At the time he was working at Needham, Harper & Steers, a Chicago, Illinois, advertising agency. The dog first showed up in a Bud Light [[Super Bowl XXI]] ad in 1987.<ref name="pet">{{cite web|url=http://www.bullterrierdallas.com/FamousBullies/spudgirl.htm |title=Spuds McKenzie: Official Party Animal |publisher=Bull Terrier Club of Dallas |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref> During the height of his popularity, large amounts of Spuds merchandise was available, such as [[plush toy]]s and [[t-shirt]]s where the dog was seen surfing a wave or ''Hanging Twenty''.<ref name="SALTY">{{cite news|title=Salty Dog History|url=https://saltydogpaddle.org/salty-dog-history.html|accessdate=6 October 2018|publisher=''saltydogpaddle.org''|date=}}</ref>
The dog, a [[Bull Terrier]], was not without its share of [[controversy]]. Shortly after Spuds' rise to fame it was learned that the dog, who was portrayed as male in the commercials, was actually female.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Zorn |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1987-09-13/news/8703090112_1_jackie-oles-honey-tree-evil-eye-spuds-mackenzie |title=Eric Zorn. Spuds Is A Dud As A Party Guy -he`s A Girl. Chicago Tribune. (Posted: September 13, 1987) |publisher=Articles.chicagotribune.com |date=1987-09-13 |accessdate=2012-10-29}}</ref> The ads were also the subject of attacks and calls for censorship by [[temperance movement|temperance]]-oriented groups. Soon after the ads were first aired in 1987, Senator [[Strom Thurmond]] began his own media campaign, claiming that the beer maker was using Spuds to appeal to children for the purpose of getting them interested in their product at an early age.<ref>{{cite news|title=Teetotaler Thurmond Raps Spuds McKenzie|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1987/Teetotaler-Thurmond-Raps-Spuds-MacKenzie-Beer-Promotion/id-03e7a81bdc59e057aa34abefeaa82cce|accessdate=23 November 2012|newspaper=Associated Press|date=13 November 1987}}</ref> By Christmas 1987, more legal action resulted from Budweiser's use of ads featuring Spuds dressed as Santa, which is illegal in states such as Ohio.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spuds Can't Promote Beer Dressed as Santa|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1987/Spuds-Can-t-Promote-Beer-Dressed-as-Santa/id-46558bab3fdc7f357896effdc47163f2|accessdate=23 November 2012|newspaper=Associated Press|date=2 December 1987}}</ref>
In 1989, the [[Center for Science in the Public Interest]], along with [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]], alleged that [[Anheuser-Busch]] was pitching the dog to children. Although the [[Federal Trade Commission]] found no evidence to support that allegation, Anheuser-Busch decided to retire Spuds in 1989, claiming that the character's image had started to overshadow the product.
The character appeared in Bud Light's advertisement in [[Super Bowl LI]] as a ghost helping a man named Brian reunite with his friends in an homage to [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''. The house number in this advertisement's last segment is 1989, paying homage to the year Spuds was retired.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Kate|title=Bud Light is bringing back a controversial mascot who once helped sales soar 20%|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/bud-light-spuds-mackenzie-super-bowl-ad-2017-2|work=Business Insider|date=February 2, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The dog's real name was '''Honey Tree Evil Eye ''' or ''Evie'' for short (October 7, 1983 – May 31, 1993).<ref name="SALTY"/> She was from [[Malvern, Pennsylvania]], but moved to [[Warsaw, Indiana]] at a very young age. She died of renal failure in [[North Riverside, Illinois|North Riverside]], [[Illinois]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Honey Tree "Spuds" Mackenzie|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/19724446|work=Find A Grave}}</ref>
Finally, in 1985 Evie also became the [[mascot]] for a surfing brand based in [[Florida]] called ''Salty Dog'', which held an annual ''Hang Twenty Surf'' Contest. The company sponsored many rescue dogs from the kennel in [[Pennsylvania]] where Evie was from.<ref name="SALTY"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Spuds Is A Dud As A Party Guy -He`S A Girl|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1987-09-13-8703090112-story.html|accessdate=6 October 2018|publisher=''chicagotribune.com''|date=}}</ref>

{{Expand German|Ständeklausel|date=September 2010}} The '''Ständeklausel''' (''[[Estates of the realm|estates]]-clause'') was a principle in poetic theatre, by which attempts were made to transfer the principles of [[French literature of the 17th century|Classicist French drama]] into German theatre. It is often connected with [[Johann Christoph Gottsched]]. It stated that only kings, princes and other people of high rank were to be shown in tragedies and that those of the middle classes could only be shown onstage in comedies. It also demarcated audiences in theatre concessions granted by ancien regime princes - only theatres in courts were allowed to put on tragedies (including ballets and serious [[opera]]s), while the rapidly proliferating Volkstheaters were only allowed to put on comedies, including [[Opéra comique|comic operas]] and pantomimes. It was broken by the onset of [[Bourgeois tragedy]] such as ''[[Love and Intrigue]]''.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Standeklausel}} [[Category:Theatre in Germany]] [[Category:17th-century theatre]] [[Category:18th-century theatre]] [[Category:19th-century theatre]]
